timeline.author: ryanemerson

timeline.bodyText: I think you can re-use CountMarshallingPojo here and just configure the org.infinispan.test.TestDataSCI
timeline.author: ryanemerson

timeline.bodyText: This made me think of ProtoStream support and then I saw that you created https://issues.redhat.com/browse/IPROTO-134 🙂
timeline.author: ryanemerson

replies.bodyText: Yes, I added this as a workaround in the tests only, to force Protostream to support it  😄
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
Couldn't we just change the test so it doesn't use primitive arrays? :)
Most cache operations won't work with primitive array keys, because the equals() implementation is wrong, and many cache operations also require equals() to work for values, so I would rather prohibit primitive array keys and values instead of adding special support in protostream.
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: Woudn't those primitive arrays marshalled form be wrapped in WrappedByteArray, so the equal and hashcode work?
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText: Yes, but that would mean primitive arrays would work or would not work depending on the cache encoding, and I would rather they work or not work the same way in any configuration.
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText:
Right, I see your point. But this was a very old test and I was just making it pass by offering an alternative that works on protostream. Protostream as a marshaller should support it IMO since every other marshaller in the world does :)
On the Infinispan side, we could document the limitation or even throw an exception if someone tries to store those arrays? In either case, I wouldn't want the change to be hidden inside this PR instead of a separate JIRA to get more visibility, as this is a breaking change
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
I agree, I over-reacted a bit to the IPROTO-134 comment because I don't want to add a new feature just to keep an old test working.
Personally I'd like to throw an exception, but we can also explore non-byte array wrappers.
replies.author: danberindei

timeline.bodyText: Why do we now get an IllegalArgumentException? I must have missed this change.
timeline.author: ryanemerson

replies.bodyText: Because protostream throws it when it can't marshall something. Before this PR, the GlobalMarshaller used to throw MarshallingException for this case
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText: Maybe we should wrap this inside ProtoStreamTranscoder#marshall with a MarshallingException and a message. Something like "Transcoder failed to marshall class %s".
replies.author: ryanemerson

timeline.bodyText: Why add the extra variable?
timeline.author: ryanemerson

replies.bodyText: I liked the extra variable, there's a lot of repetition in this test :)
replies.author: danberindei

timeline.bodyText: Nitpick, could you split the array over multiple lines like in the other @AutoProtoSchemaBuilder
timeline.author: ryanemerson

timeline.bodyText: Is this for this PR?
timeline.author: ryanemerson

replies.bodyText: let me check if this is still needed
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText: For now, I will just remove this TODO and handle it in the next PR
replies.author: gustavonalle

timeline.message: ISPN-11478 Remove GlobalMarshaller usage on OFF_HEAP/BINARY

timeline.bodyText: Is this is needed at all? All the constructors already have a storageMediaType parameter.
timeline.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: This was added to avoid requiring caches to configure a storage media type, and to assume sensible defaults. We can discuss if this config should be mandatory or not, but this is out of scope for this PR
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
IIUC injectDependencies() is only called on the remote nodes, not on the origin node. But storageMediaType is not transient, so the value coming from the origin node should be good enough. Or if injectDependencies() is also called on the origin node, then we don't need to initialize it in the constructor.
Or were you thinking about a cache that is configured with one storage media type on node A and another storage media type on node B? I'm pretty sure that would break lots of other things, because we don't transcode values in non-functional commands.
I'm fine with splitting it in a separate JIRA btw, since you're just adding a parameter here, but I would like to clarify it at some point.
replies.author: danberindei
gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
I was wrong, injectDependencies() is called, it just skips most of the initialization, including that of storageMediaType (see line 167).
Reading that code again, the initialization is skipped only for the DataConversion.DEFAULT_* static instances, so you are right, the storageMediaType is recomputed.
Speaking of the static instances, however, the line this.encoderRegistry = encoderRegistry; should be moved below the if so that they stay constant.
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: One more thing: since we only wire the dependency into DataConversion instances, but we never register them in the component registry, I suggest changing @Scope(NAMED_CACHE) to @Scope(NONE).
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: Moving the this.encoderRegistry = encoderRegistry below the if breaks a bunch of stuff, since the registry can be used in convertToRequestFormat()
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText: @gustavonalle the if should only apply to the static instances like DataConversion.DEFAULT_KEY. The encoder registry is a component, so 2 nodes running in the same JVM will overwrite each other's encoderRegistry reference, which I don't think is correct.
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText:
AFAICT, the same encoder registry instance is inject in all data conversions of all caches, it's a cache manager level component. If you have 2 nodes in the same JVM, I suppose each node will have a different one, but they won't mix?
ok, I understood what you meant, let me see if I can change it...
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
Actually, I won't do this for this PR, as it's unrelated.
https://issues.redhat.com/browse/ISPN-11620
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText: Excellent, I was actually testing my changes locally and came to the same conclusion: a DataConversion instance should only convert between the storage type and the request type, the transcoder lookup should be elsewhere.
replies.author: danberindei

timeline.bodyText: IMO if the cache has a user marshaller and the storage type is not OBJECT, then the cache should already be initialized with the user marshaller's media type as the storage type, we shouldn't do this check only when the DataConversion is shipped to another node and has its dependencies injected.
timeline.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: Could you clarify? The DataConversion is initialized when the cache is initialized, it's a component. Also the information about storage type, request type, transcoder, etc is part of the DataConversion
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
I meant the user marshaller and the storage type must be in sync. I don't see any point in allowing a cache to be configured with both
<value media-type="application/x-protostream"/>
and
<serialization marshaller="org.infinispan.jboss.marshalling.core.JBossUserMarshaller"/>

it's a component.

Exactly. There is a DataConversion component, but most of the injectDependencies() logic is skipped for that instance because the same class is trying to be 2 things at the same time.
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText:
The pair <value media-type="application/x-protostream"/> and <serialization marshaller="org.infinispan.jboss.marshalling.core.JBossUserMarshaller"/> is possible. The later is cache-manager scoped, the former cache scope config.
It means the cache will store protobuf and a transcoder that is able to convert between application/x-jboss-marshaller <=> application/x-java-object is registered. This transcoder can be used whenever another cache needs that conversion
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
Good point, I was thinking of the user marshaller as a purely "to/from storage" thing, but it's obvious now that it could also be a "to/from request" thing.
However, PersistenceManagerImpl.createUserMarshaller() ignores the cache's storage media type, so storageMediaType will always be set to the user marshaller's media type.
And it also made me realize that the <value media-type="X"/> configuration serves a dual purpose. It was even more complicated before, but with your changes IIUC

With <binary/>, the storage type is X, and the default request type is application/x-java-object.
With <object/>, the storage type is application/x-java-object, and the default request type is X.
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText:
Going back to your initial point, injectDependencies() should be always called when the cache is created, otherwise I fear for the transcoding stuff 😄
An alternative to what was done here, that aligns with your suggestion, is to move this logic to configuration time, more precisely, if a cache is heap (OBJECT) and don't have a MediaType configured, let's set the key/value mediatype to the "user marshaller". I will try doing that.
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
<value media-type="X"/>

This has a single purpose, define the format of the values in the cache. This is configuration and cannot be changed at runtime. If not specified, a best guess will be made, e.g., indexed server caches will be protobuf otherwise there's no way of having query to work.
The request type will be app/x-java-object by default, and it's changeable at runtime, that's how the server deals with multiple request formats in REST, for example.
I will rather say what is planned for the BINARY/OFF_HEAP/OBJECT trio after the last PR which is https://issues.redhat.com/browse/ISPN-11424:

BINARY and OBJECT disappears
OFF_HEAP is a flag on/off to specify if data will be stored in heap or not
if off_heap=true for a cache, then we check the media type: it it's not byte[] based format, we throw an exception.

So we're left only with the mediatype and a flag heap/off-heap
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
@danberindei WRT:

IMO if the cache has a user marshaller and the storage type is not OBJECT, then the cache should already be initialized with the user marshaller's media type as the storage type

I was not able to set the MediaType of the cache at configuration time, since the user marshaller is initialized at runtime and doesn't necessary follow the <serialization> configuration.
WRT:

But please have another look at the user marshaller and whether its media type can override the cache's media type with the current code

When the DataConversion is initialized, it gives priority to the configured MediaType:
https://github.com/infinispan/infinispan/blob/master/core/src/main/java/org/infinispan/encoding/DataConversion.java#L126-L128
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
<value media-type="X"/> [...] has a single purpose, define the format of the values in the cache.

Sorry you had to spell that out again, I read "user marshaller can be used both ways" and I jumped to "content type configuration can also be used both ways". I guess I couldn't accept that the encoding configuration would be simply ignored for caches with OBJECT storage :)

When the DataConversion is initialized, it gives priority to the configured MediaType:

I missed that too!

I was not able to set the MediaType of the cache at configuration time

If you mean during ConfigurationBuilder.build() then I agree, we can't query the user marshaller at that time.
My thinking was that the storage type could be computed in InternalCacheFactory.buildEncodingCache(), so it doesn't have to be recomputed every time the DataConversion instance is sent to another node.
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: Let me try that
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText: It didn't work: during InternalCacheFactory.buildEncodingCache() the persistence marshaller is null in the registry
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
Yeah, the component registry is not yet bootstrapped there. But the persistence marshaller is a global component, so it doesn't need the cache component registry.
Here's how I would like it to work: c864043
Let me know if you want to include my suggestions here, otherwise I can integrate your PR as is and open a separate PR.
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: Cool, let's separate from this PR please
replies.author: gustavonalle

timeline.bodyText: Missing whitespace
timeline.author: danberindei

timeline.bodyText: There seems to be a disconnect between marshall and unmarshall... marshall decides whether to wrap the byte array (whatever that means) based on the wrapped parameter, while unmarshall decides whether the byte array is wrapped or not based on the type parameter. At the very least this deserves a comment to explain the difference. /cc @ryanemerson
timeline.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText:
When producing protobuf from Something, it's possible to serialize to the protobuf wire format directly or to serialize using a message wrapper containing the protobuf payload, aka  org.infinispan.protostream.WrappedMessage
This is used in RemoteQuery, that needs to serialize to those two formats (user payload and query structure itself)
AFAICT, when umarshalling, it will automatically work 😄
I will add some test/doc to this
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
👍
I don't doubt this feature is needed, I just wanted an explanation of how the wrapped and type parameters work together.
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: Hope it makes sense now?  ;)
replies.author: gustavonalle

timeline.bodyText: What storage type does the cache injected in components have, if not the storage media type?
timeline.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: .withStorageMediaType() changes the request media type, not the storage media type; this call is simply giving to the interceptor a cache instance that will not try to convert from whatever is stored
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
Sorry, I bungled my question.
I meant why wouldn't the cache injected in components already have the request media type == the storage media type, so that it doesn't do any conversion? The media type of the EncoderCache wrapper is going to be passed as a parameter anyway.
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText:
By default, all caches have a request type of application/x-java-object. This was added in the previous issue https://issues.redhat.com/browse/ISPN-11446
Some components (query, interceptors, etc) need to operate on the data as stored, that's why this decoration was creted
replies.author: gustavonalle

timeline.bodyText: A method would be clearer IMO
timeline.author: danberindei

timeline.bodyText:
"16 more" suddenly doesn't seem that important :)
IMO we should remove these comments, I'd rather replace the constants in the code (e.g. line 217) with calculations to explain how we got the 144 or 104 bytes of overhead, or maybe a link to another place where the overhead is explained.
timeline.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: I am not sure about the magic numbers from OFF_HEAP, but I will document the ones from BINARY
replies.author: gustavonalle

timeline.bodyText: putIfAbsent isn't functional, as the method name implies.

replies.bodyText:
Good guy IntelliJ!
However, since you mentioned ComputeCommand is not really a functional command, maybe the test name was never correct :))
replies.author: danberindei

timeline.bodyText:
Why keep the random number?
But the bigger problem is that CountMarshallingPojo uses static fields for the marshall count, and it breaks when 2 of the many tests that use it run in parallel. Either it should have a custom raw marshaller, with a different marshaller instance in each test, or it should have a test name field and it should maintain a map of marshall counts per test.

replies.bodyText: I did not write this test, I was just migrating it to protostream, but I can change it no problem

replies.bodyText: In fact @ryanemerson suggested the CountMarshallingPojo, I had my own private one, I will just go back to that then
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText: I would have rather you fixed CountMarshallingPojo, because it's already used in multiple tests anyway, but know what you mean :)

replies.bodyText: I've created https://issues.redhat.com/browse/ISPN-11604 so that the issue isn't forgotten.
replies.author: ryanemerson

timeline.bodyText: A static method would be clearer IMO, it's always applied directly.

Is this really necessary? I thought JCache doesn't allow the user to override the data conversion.

timeline.bodyText: What's the expected media type for a Lucene cache? Couldn't you test for that instead of !APPLICATION_UNKNOWN?

replies.bodyText:
The user can create/configure Lucene caches, so there is no way of knowing.
In any case, Lucene caches are being removed on #8137.
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
I meant e.g. org.infinispan.query.impl.LifecycleManager#getDefaultLuceneCacheConfig uses MediaType.APPLICATION_OBJECT_TYPE, shouldn't you say that the cache is custom if the media type is != APPLICATION_OBJECT_TYPE?
In practice the result may be the same, but the comment isn't very clear to me.

replies.bodyText:
if I disable transcoding when mediaType != APPLICATION_OBJECT_TYPE it will break Lucene caches that are configured with OFF_HEAP/BINARY.
But Lucene caches are literally hours ahead of being removed from master, so I will not try changing this :)

replies.bodyText: Ok :)

Missing whitespace (also on line 401)
Also, the javadoc of Wrapper.isFilterable() says true if the wrapped format is suitable to be indexed or filtered, thus avoiding extra unwrapping, but here you're doing the unwrapping in the true case. Maybe the javadoc is referring to something else?

replies.bodyText: I am not unwrapping the value (that is filterable), but the key in this method. Let me see if I can simplify this, I agree it's convoluted

timeline.bodyText:
Here too, if the cache injected in components has request media type == storage media type, then the conversion isn't necessary.
Edit: You would still have to convert the value to the request media type, but I would rather make that conversion explicit here instead of converting the key back and forth.
timeline.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: This cache has the default request type, but the QueryInterceptor now indexes keys in the storage format. I did that change because it was always indexing the key in the request format, which is inefficient, since the QueryInterceptor was already receiving the key in the storage format (and was converting back again).
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText:
I agree 100% that QueryInterceptor should index the key in the storage format.
My assertion was that the Cache instance should not have the default request type, in fact it should not be an EncoderCache instance at all.
replies.author: danberindei

replies.bodyText: let me see if I can make a non-encoded cache arrive to this command, can't make any promises  :)
replies.author: gustavonalle

replies.bodyText: ok, I changed it

timeline.bodyText:
Can you make use of one of the POJOs in TestDataSCI, say Key or Person. That way we don't need yet another test class and SerializationContextInitializer implementation.
When I originally made ProtoStream the default I managed to remove a lot of duplicated code from the testsuite by removing internal test classes like these. So it would be great if we could stick to the already provided ones. This is a trivial Pojo, so it should work correctly unlike CountMarshallingPojo 😅
timeline.author: ryanemerson

replies.bodyText: Done
replies.author: gustavonalle
